text: know what I'm gonna listen to some
hip-hop I don't think so buddy hi
everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review a
Saab Rock skeleton a stop rock was once
in the late 1990s and early 2000s a very
prominent figure in underground hip hop
back when underground hip hop was not
really as big as it is now thanks to the
internet I would actually go as far as
to say he is like the ultimate nerd MC
and I don't mean like the the
fashionable cool kind of nerd image that
were faced with all too often today
look at me I'm quirky I wear thick
glasses and I'm into really obscure
stuff I'm living a lie
instead I definitely give a stop the
nerd of the Year award for his is very
dense and well read lyrics regularly
employing words that will have you
getting up to grab the nearest
dictionary to decipher what the hell
he's saying and even though it can be
really difficult to read into this guy's
lyrics for me it's truly the only way
you can fully appreciate and enjoy his
music because he's not the kind of emcee
who's going to sit back and make a poppy
track where you can kind of just tune
him out and just vibe to the
instrumental in my opinion a saps early
stuff is great of course it's very wordy
at times very passionate and and catchy
the instrumentals on his earlier LP is
to have a more I guess traditional sound
to them but a stops I guess progression
past his earlier work has been a bit of
a double-edged sword for me while I do
feel like his songs have become more
conceptual his verbiage has
come just heavier on the album none
shall pass he started kind of taking on
this this sharp like somewhat forced
grasp to his vocal delivery and not
really varying that all too much and I
feel like that kind of kills his vocal
dynamic a bit and makes things ever so
slightly redundant and admittedly it
took me a little while to kind of get
past it too and it took me a while to
review this album as well and it's
mostly because it's it's been a long
time since I've kind of sat down and
intently listened to an album from this
guy with-with-with now what continues to
amaze me about this guy is just his aw
inspiringly detailed approach to rapping
about things that I feel like past most
people buy on an everyday basis for
example the track fryer starter which is
kind of about a late-night trip to a
California donut shop and it kind of
touches down on everything from
sprinkles to the various styles and
flavors to double chins and the
instrumental and and an Aesop's voice
itself have a very kind of creepy eerie
and strange the aura around them and it
just makes me think man do you
contemplate everything so deeply he
definitely can turn something normal
into something eerie but on another
track he turned something that is kind
of childish and silly into an intense
battle for dietary sovereignty the track
is Grace and it's really a SAP kind of
wrapping from the perspective of himself
as a child not wanting to eat the greens
on his plate for dinner and lyrically he
just builds the climax higher and higher
and higher as the track progresses the
stories on here can get I guess
legitimately dark though the track Ruby
81 is really one of my favorites on
skeleton
and it features him kind of rapping over
this throbbing drone that sounds like it
could have come from a horror movie
soundtrack or something and the story
itself is is kind of about this kid who
slips away from from her mother's
attention during a 4th of July fireworks
show and nearly drowns in a pool but it
does kind of have a happy and
animal-related ending but I will say
this album is more about endings than it
is happiness because if there is one
huge theme that links most of these
tracks together it is death the Trank
zero dark thirty kind of seems to be
about a stop putting weaker rappers out
of their misery and he talks about doing
this with with just such were Deaver
tsa's you wouldn't think that's what the
song is actually about it's very subtle
braggadocio sness i guess and on the
track crows which has Kimya Dawson
singing on the hook and she is a really
nice creepy addition to the song her and
a stop kind of spit all over the
tradition of celebrating the dead with
with tombstones and rock monuments when
really all you're doing in the ground
under that monument is just rotting the
track homemade mummy on here brings more
of it to another level and literally
talks about the instructions for
mummification but kind of uses a cat as
its guinea pig so to speak a few of the
tracks leading up to the finish of this
album have some pretty grimy beats and
some stray spitting from a stop I love
those tracks a lot and this album is
bookended by these two songs that that
kind of paint this current self-portrait
of ASAP as this guy who is a loner maybe
slightly suicidal and even though his
isolation is self-imposed it's also kind
of driving him insane it's a dark
picture but one of the most sincere and
and raw moments on this album poetically
I feel
a stop is as good as he's ever been
that's to be expected but this album
does present a first for him though it
is the first time he is handling all the
production on one of his LPS for sure
this is a cohesive album but I do feel
like some of the hooks are lacking on
this thing for example the third track
on here the hook is so understated it
might as well not even be there and the
track racing stripes just seems to be I
guess so odd and silly not only rapping
about kind of haircuts and some funny
stories behind them but the track just
really kind of feels too indulgent for
me and the instrumental adds to that but
when it comes to the beats on here while
it is not my favorite production of the
year it is pretty solid and does the job
I really love the classic rock drum
fills and the heavy guitar chords on the
track zze top the pulsating stints on
the track zero dark thirty have a nice
tension to them the beat four fryer
starter is very eerie and creepy and
kind of becomes hilarious given the
subject matter I talked about before
there are some spots where I kind of
catch deja vu tracks that have a drum
sample that is dirtied up just a smidge
with a kind of muddy bassline songs like
thousand o'clock or Tetra there are
several songs or instrumentals on this
LP like that so I do kind of catch a bit
of deja vu from time to time with the
beats I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light
8 on this thing what did you guys think
of it if you've listened to it did you
love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantana ASAP rock
forever
